name: Minneapolis
fun_fact: Fun fact: Minneapolis has the most Somali immigrants of any city in America, creating the country's most vibrant Somali food scene, while also being the birthplace of the Juicy Lucy burger - proving that culinary diversity and cheese-stuffed excess can coexist perfectly.

hero_dishes.name: Juicy Lucy (Jucy Lucy)
hero_dishes.description: A cheese-stuffed burger that oozes molten cheese with every bite - Minneapolis's greatest contribution to American cuisine
hero_dishes.origin_story: Created in the 1950s at either Matt's Bar or the 5-8 Club (both claim invention), this inside-out cheeseburger became a Minneapolis icon. The spelling 'Jucy Lucy' is fiercely defended by Matt's Bar
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Matt's Bar (original 'Jucy Lucy'), 5-8 Club (rival claimant), Blue Door Pub (creative versions)

hero_dishes.name: Pre-Colonial Indigenous Cuisine at Owamni
hero_dishes.description: Modern Indigenous dishes using only ingredients native to North America - no dairy, wheat, or cane sugar
hero_dishes.origin_story: Founded by James Beard Award winner Sean Sherman (The Sioux Chef), Owamni represents a cultural revival of Indigenous foodways. Dishes showcase wild rice, bison, duck, game, and foraged ingredients
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Owamni (on the Mississippi River - James Beard Award winner)

hero_dishes.name: Wild Rice Dishes
hero_dishes.description: Minnesota's official state grain featured in soups, pancakes, burgers, and porridge - nutty, hearty, and locally harvested
hero_dishes.origin_story: Wild rice has been harvested by Indigenous peoples in Minnesota for thousands of years. It's the only grain native to North America and remains central to the region's identity
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Hell's Kitchen (Native-harvested wild rice porridge), The Mill Northeast (wild rice pancakes), Common Roots CafÃ© (vegan wild rice burger)

hero_dishes.name: Walleye
hero_dishes.description: Minnesota's most sought-after fish, served beer-battered, pan-fried, or as crispy walleye fingers
hero_dishes.origin_story: Walleye is the state fish and the holy grail of Minnesota fishing. Locals take walleye preparation very seriously - it should be fresh, locally caught, and never overcooked
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Gluek's (famous walleye fingers), Hell's Kitchen (beer-battered or pan-fried), Zelo (walleye milanese)

signature_drinks.name: Grain Belt Beer
signature_drinks.description: Minneapolis's iconic local beer since 1893 - a crisp, no-frills lager
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Grain Belt is the beer of choice at dive bars, fish fries, and backyard cookouts. The vintage neon sign on the Mississippi is a city landmark

signature_drinks.name: Nordic-Style Aquavit Cocktails
signature_drinks.description: Cocktails featuring aquavit and other Scandinavian spirits, reflecting the city's Nordic heritage
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: At upscale bars and restaurants celebrating Minneapolis's Scandinavian roots. The Nordic influence runs deep in the Twin Cities

food_culture_notes: Minneapolis won two James Beard Awards in 2025 - BÃ»cheron for Best New Restaurant and Hai Hai's Christina Nguyen for Best Chef Midwest
The city has a huge Nordic influence (Norwegian, Swedish, Finnish) alongside vibrant Somali, Hmong, Vietnamese, and Mexican communities
Spoon and Stable by Gavin Kaysen is set in a restored horse stable and uses French techniques on Midwest ingredients
Cheese curds (fried or fresh) are a Minnesota obsession - try them with berry ketchup at Red Cow or Thousand Island at Bull's Horn

unique_modern: year-round outdoor culture despite brutal winters
